body: @junrao I updated the patch based on your suggestion. I did not add a method to the NetworClient because it is sort of a public API. So instead I passed the client into the `abortExpriedBatches` and check if the leader is disconnected.
LGTM
Yeah, sorry @granthenke, was pushing through the minor fix since it'd be confusing in RC docs, but there's still quite a bit of docs follow up for 0.10.0.0 I think.
LGTM

Another related thing is that the send ordering is not really guaranteed with retry when max.inflight.requests > 1. For example, when retried batches are added back to accumulator, they may not be in the send order. So, in this case, the sequence of timing out retried batches is not necessarily guaranteed to be ordered.
Good to see these documentation improvements. :)
Nice that the fix is so small. Would it be possible to write a test that would fail before and pass now?
@ijuma Might be possible in an integration test. I'll have a look.
Thanks!
Is it any semantic changes here? Will commit be performed without explicit call of `poll`?

@hachikuji Do you actually need an integration test? Doesn't the exception get triggered from `ConsumerNetworkClient` (before you hit any mocks in `ConsumerCoordinatorTest`) and then get propagated to the callback for `commitOffsetsAsync`? So shouldn't this be testable just by doing exactly what the bug report says in a test in `ConsumerCoordinatorTest`?

@junrao I guess if max.in.flight.requests > 1, the timeout order does not really matter at that point either. In general, when there are Exceptions, the callback order is only guaranteed if max.in.flight.request = 1. Otherwise, the later batch could have a non-retriable exception and got failed immediately when the earlier batch is waiting for a retry.

@ewencp It's a bit awkward to test this through `MockClient`, which is what all the coordinator tests are using. I'm not sure you can do it in a way that doesn't amount to asserting that poll() is called in commitAsync(). It's really the integration between `ConsumerNetworkClient` and `ConsumerCoordinator` that needs testing. I guess your concern is creeping build time (more than 11 minutes now)?

@13h3r This changes behavior in two ways: (1) the commit will be sent when commitAsync() is called, and (2) commitAsync() can trigger heartbeats. My guess is that (1) is probably how users think this API works anyway. I really can't see a case where a user would depend on commitAsync() _not_ sending the commit. For users who are doing the standard poll loop, the difference won't be noticeable. For (2), this won't affect externally observed behavior at all, except that users won't fall out of the group as quickly ;-).
Modified version for the python tests based on advice from @granders. @ewencp - can you take another look?

@hachikuji I am worried about creeping build time, but also just hoping that it was testable via unit tests because they are much easier to debug/fix if anything changes. If an integration test is the way to go given current test setup and the code, go for it. I only mentioned the unit test approach because that test seems to use real versions of `ConsumerNetworkClient` and `ConsumerCoordinator` and I thought the `MockClient` could return a successful indicator for the first commit request and then the `ConsumerNetworkClient` would take care of failing any subsequent requests and invoking the callback. But I didn't look that closely yet to understand any implementation challenges there, I trust you if you say it doesn't work :)

LGTM based on matching version number for the branch. This actually is a bit weird since we'll have a bunch of commits w/ technically incorrect versions and I'm not sure what kind of havoc this wreaks on anything that publishes artifacts (i.e. jenkins), but I guess we'll see :)
@ewencp You might be right. I had forgotten that we use `ConsumerNetworkClient` directly. Let me see what that looks like.
@ewencp I ended up doing the integration test. We'd need to change the send behavior of `MockClient` to actually test the case that this patch is trying to fix.

@becketqin - if this passes review (and is well tested!) before next Monday, we can include this in the next RC. otherwise, it may need to go into trunk and wait for next release (but you guys are running trunk anyway...)
LGTM
@junrao - I've removed the use of Hamcrest & rebased post rack awareness changes. Tests pass locally. Please could you merge.

Also, we need to properly handle the returning of a partial message when doing the down conversion. Left a comment on the jira.

Has this been re-opened? I agree it would be nice to have in 0.10

@granthenke Not yet. I will do so later today. We're debating on what the default values should be for some of the new fields. We already use -1 for the serializedKeyLength and serializedValueLength when the key or value are null, so it seems like we need something else to indicate absence of the fields.
@gwenshap do you think we need to do anything else before removing the annotation?
@guozhangwang @ijuma Thanks for having a look. I've added an update to address your comments.
Just a minor comment on property names in strings, otherwise LGTM.
@gwenshap Any reason this can't get into 0.10?

@granthenke  Well, lack of LGTM at the moment.
I'll try to get to it this week, but can't promise.

@gwenshap gotcha. This patch reduces the valid topic name length to 249 (from 255) and adds test coverage and documentation. It's a LGTM for me. 

@vahidhashemian Anything else you need to do yet for this patch?

Maybe decide what the annotation actually means and figure out some kind of consistent policy on when those are removed? I think we had a JIRA about that specifically.

We also have Kafka Connect and Kafka Streams coming up. Will be nice to figure anything out and not change things completely randomly. There are currently 3 semi-related places where we communicate the "maturity" of the APIs:
- Unstable annotation
- Beta in the docs
- Use in tooling (i.e. use of --new vs --old flag)
- Deprecation of older APIs.

Will be nice to get some consistency around when we do what :)

If either of you have time to do a draft guideline, we can re-evaluate the removal based on that?

The jira for deciding the "meaning of the annotations" is [KAFKA-3433](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3433) the guideline I was following is whats in code now. 
- Unstable: No guarantee is provided as to reliability or stability across any level of release granularity.
- Evolving: Evolving, but can break compatibility at minor release (i.e. m.x)
- Stable: Can evolve while retaining compatibility for minor release boundaries can break compatibility only at major release (ie. at m.0)

I am not sure Stable is needed since that the "default" case.

I was wondering about how do we decide it is stable now?

I mean, considering KIP-45, it is probably de-facto stable... but I was thinking we may want to have an answer for "when is a component considered stable".
cc @ewencp @gwenshap

True, I am not sure how/when. I suppose it needs to be done on a case by case basis and whenever the community agrees we are going to follow the rules laid out. 

In this case are we no longer going to break the new consumer interface in a minor or maintenance release?

The other thing not concretely defined is what a major or minor or maintenance release are. I think we are following semantic versioning just with a leading 0 (i.e. 0.Major.Minor.Maintenance), that may not be clear to users less familiar with Kafka.
@hachikuji Could you incorporate @granthenke 's feedback before merging?
LGTM but can we get Jenkins to pass?

ok, sounds good.

I'll merge since this is defacto stable and we'll come up with guidelines later.
Awesome.

LGTM. 

As a follow-up - will be nice to have a more "programmatic" way to mark configuration as deprecated, so we can log WARN messages when deprecated configs are used and maybe help users stop using them...
Started a new Jenkins build.
Unfortunately, I had to relocate max.poll.records above the session.timeout.ms to be able to refer to it in the description. If that's too annoying, I can revert the commit.

LGTM. Merged to trunk.
LGTM

cc @becketqin @SinghAsDev @ijuma 

This is not significantly different from Ashish's patch, but I've added a log statement to give users more guidance if they see this occurring regularly. I think there's more we could be doing internally to mitigate this problem. For example, maybe it makes sense to set a default max.poll.records. Also we currently just block in the send loop after polling the records in receive(), but we probably should abort that loop immediately when the session timeout expires since we'll have no chance of committing offsets anyway. We _could_ try to tackle some of this in this patch, but I'm thinking of opening a separate JIRA since a bigger change will be harder to get into 0.10. Thoughts?
@hachikuji, filing a separate JIRA for the additional improvements sounds good to me.
This should be double committed to trunk + 0.10.0
Thanks.
@ewencp Sorry I missed this. I did a local build. It seams sometimes Gradle doesn't run checkstyle unless you explicitly call `clean`. I will open a jira to fix that.

I talked with @ijuma briefly about whether we should deprecate the old constructor. The main downside is that users who are constructing this object in test cases aren't going to have any clue what to use for the serialized lengths and the checksum. In that case, they'd probably use default or arbitrary values. So the old constructor might be worth leaving around just for convenience. On a similar note, it might be worth adding an additional constructor which includes the timestamp, but not the checksum and serialized lengths.
Thanks for catching this @hachikuji. Is it worth adding a test using the constructor? Otherwise LGTM.
@granthenke Couldn't hurt. Since you're here, do you have any thoughts on deprecation?
@hachikuji I am a bit indifferent. It's not a ton of code to keep around, and if it becomes a problem we can deprecate it then. So I am okay with not deprecating it.
cc @ijuma @SinghAsDev @ewencp @gwenshap
I'd also prefer this PR. Sorry for jumping on this late @ijuma .

Thanks @ijuma for guiding me there. I will try to add the unit test soon.
I don't think this particular patch is relevant anymore. Closing
cc @junrao
@auradkar, are you sure? It doesn't seem like anything changed that would make it irrelevant. What am I missing?

@ijuma - I think I closed it prematurely based on a discussion I had with @jjkoshy a while ago. I'm unable to recollect the details of that conversation accurately.

Basically, I thought that the makeLeader would be triggered only when the current host is a follower i.e. it is being promoted to a leader. In that case, this condition would never be hit because inSyncReplicas.size would be 0 and the condition I am asserting for couldn't be true. However, makeLeader can also be called on the current leader, in which case this metric is accurate.
Rebased.
@gwenshap I think you need to close this manually since it's against the 0.10.0 branch

Thanks for the reminder, @ewencp

I think the setting is a good default and I think the addition of `KAFKA_NETWORK_OPTS` is a good idea. How do we feel about this being public interface? Hate to complicate things, but as part of CLI technically this is public and may need to go through a KIP. Otherwise I'd say LGTM and commit.
I think we didn't do KIPs for small changes like this one in the past (similarly we have added options to CLI tools without a KIP).
On second thought, changing the default could affect existing users so it may be worth a mailing list discussion.
It has been suggested that it may be better not to depend on MiniKdc at all, so I'll resubmit with that in mind.
LGTM, thanks!
